title: 114_hr4216
content: The Act is titled the "Consumer Financial Choice and Capital Markets Protection Act of 2015." It amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include provisions regarding money market funds. The Act, titled the "Consumer Financial Choice and Capital Markets Protection Act of 2015," allows open-end investment companies to elect to be treated as money market funds. They can use the amortized cost method of valuation or penny-rounding method of pricing for their securities, regardless of shareholder limitations, if certain criteria are met. The Act allows open-end investment companies to elect to be treated as money market funds and use the amortized cost valuation method or penny-rounding pricing method for their securities, as specified in the Code of Federal Regulations. The directors of the company have determined that it is in the best interests of the company to use specific valuation methods for the money market fund, as long as the resulting share price reflects the market-based net asset value. The company agrees to comply with quality, maturity, diversification, and liquidity requirements set by the Commission. The company agrees to comply with quality, maturity, diversification, and liquidity requirements set by the Commission for the protection of investors. Prohibition against federal government bailouts of money market funds includes definitions of covered Federal assistance. The company must comply with regulations set by the Commission to protect investors, including restrictions on federal government bailouts for money market funds. Covered Federal assistance includes insurance, guarantees, and advances from specific Federal Reserve facilities. The regulations prohibit direct Federal assistance to money market funds, requiring disclosure in prospectuses and sales materials. The SEC may establish rules for this disclosure after consulting with relevant agencies. Investors must receive disclosure in a specified manner. A company opting to be a money market fund must comply with regulations applicable to registered open-end companies, as long as they do not conflict with this section.
